front.title: Deprecating obsolete DNS Resource Records Types

abstract.t: This document deprecates Resource Records (RR) Types that are either not being used for anything meaningful or were been already made obsolete by other RFCs. This document updates , , .

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The defines couple of old resource records that are not being used, and they are either causing operational problems between implementations that support them and that don't supported them due DNS compression on the wire, or they are not in use and should have been obsoleted years ago. This document deprecates such records to allow the implementations to drop the specific support for such records.

section.title: Deprecating MB, MG, MF, MINFO and WKS RR Types
section.t: The MB, MG, MF, MINFO, and WKS RR Types aren't used in any existing standards, and this documents deprecates the usage. The MB, MG, MF, and MINFO RR Types contain a domain name that could be compressed in the RDATA section. The DNS implementations compliant with this document MUST NOT implement MB, MG, MF, WKS, and MINFO RR Types and treat them as a unknown DNS Resource RR Types (), effectively disabling the message compression inside the RDATA of aforementioned RRTYPEs.

As an update to and this document specifies that for MB, MG, MF, MINFO, and WKS RR types, the canonical form is such that no downcasing of embedded domain names takes place, and otherwise identical to the canonical form specified in section 6.2.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This documents updates the IANA registry "Domain Name System (DNS) Parameters" ().

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document has not security considerations.

section.title: Operational Considerations
section.t: The various state of implementation of MB, MG, MR, MINFO, and WKS records is already causing operational problems between DNS implementations that do implement aforementioned types and those who don't because of the DNS compression on the wire. This document aims to rectify the situation by removing the support for all these RR types the DNS implementations. This should not cause any operational problems because the records aren't actually in use on the Internet. [COMMENT: Some data?]
